title: How to Make Time Pass Quickly When You’re Looking Forward to Something

steps.title: Break up the hours into 5- or 10-minute blocks.
steps.content: Break up the hours into 5- or 10-minute blocks. Use the blocks to alternate back and forth between fully focusing on a task or activity and working at a more relaxed pace. Focusing on something can help the time pass quickly, and breaking it up into chunks can make it more manageable. [1] X Trustworthy Source Edutopia Educational nonprofit organization focused on encouraging and celebrating classroom innovation Go to source For instance, you could break up an hour by alternating between 5- and 10-minute chunks. Spend the 10-minute chunks really focusing on a task. Then, spend the 5-minute blocks relaxing and working less hard.

steps.title: Use audio and visual stimulation to distract yourself.
steps.content: Use audio and visual stimulation to distract yourself. Watch some TV or put on a movie. Pull out your phone and look up some videos, or put on a good playlist to listen to some of your favorite songs. You’ll distract your mind to help the time pass more quickly. [2] X Research source

steps.title: Immerse yourself in another world by reading.
steps.content: Immerse yourself in another world by reading . Crack open a new book or an old classic that you love to read over and over. Transport your mind to a different time and place to pass the time. Engrossing yourself in a good book helps keep your mind fully occupied, and you likely won’t even notice the hours fly by. [3] X Research source Try listening to an audiobook if you don’t have a hard copy in front of you.

steps.title: Play around on the internet to kill some time.
steps.content: Play around on the internet to kill some time. Pull out your phone or hop on a computer and look up cat videos or find the latest updates of your favorite sports. Check out social media and see what your friends are up to. Take a look at some of the latest memes and have a few laughs, or send them to friends you think would like them. You’ll be surprised how quickly the time passes. [4] X Trustworthy Source American Psychological Association Leading scientific and professional organization of licensed psychologists Go to source

steps.title: Put together a to-do list
steps.content: Put together a to-do list for your future. Channel your boredom into a productive task by jotting down goals or dreams that you have. Open up a digital note or grab a piece of paper and a pen. Then, come up with goals for today, the end of the week, and the end of the month. You can also think about tasks you need to complete to make those goals happen. In the end, you'll have a solid game plan you can use to improve your future. [5] X Research source Life coach Jessica Elliot advises to approach your goals in small, incremental steps. By doing a few things every day, you're adding to your overall larger goal. Take your time when approaching your goals. Slow things down, take it day-by-day, and understand that there's beauty hidden in the journey.

steps.title: Tackle that to-do list you’ve been putting off.
steps.content: Tackle that to-do list you’ve been putting off. Find some stuff you can clean up around your home, such as washing the dishes or vacuuming. Clear out your fridge and wipe down the counters to get your kitchen tidied up. You could also do some of that laundry that’s been piling up or organize your garage. Get to those less-than-desirable tasks, and you’ll pass the time and feel accomplished when you’re finished. [6] X Trustworthy Source HelpGuide Nonprofit organization dedicated to providing free, evidence-based mental health and wellness resources. Go to source

steps.title: Use this simple trick to make time go by faster.
steps.content: Use this simple trick to make time go by faster. Instead of counting the time, start counting from 100 to 1. As you count, you won’t notice the time passing, and counting down can feel like you’re reaching a goal. Mix it up and force your mind to focus by counting down by 2s, 5s, or something tricky like 7s. You could even count from 1000 to 1 to take up more time. [7] X Research source Counting up can make it feel like you’re counting the seconds, which could actually make it seem like time is passing more slowly. So, always aim to count down.

steps.title: Reach out and catch up to pass the time.
steps.content: Reach out and catch up to pass the time. Take some time to give a call or shoot a message to an old friend or a relative you haven’t talked to in a while. You could talk about the latest news and update each other about your lives. Having other people to talk to can make the time pass faster. [8] X Research source

steps.title: Make your mind and body feel better.
steps.content: Make your mind and body feel better. Take a nice walk or go for a bike ride. A Stanford study found that walking increases creativity and has a positive impact on your mood. [9] X Trustworthy Source HelpGuide Nonprofit organization dedicated to providing free, evidence-based mental health and wellness resources. Go to source You could also head to the gym to get a really good workout in. Exercise releases endorphins that can make you feel happier and more relaxed, and while you’re focusing on exercising, you won’t think about the time as much. You don’t necessarily have to exercise, but some time outside can help boost your mood. If you can’t exercise outside, working out or relaxing indoors can also kill some time.

steps.title: Practice mindfulness
steps.content: Practice mindfulness to become absorbed in the moment. Observe your surroundings and notice all of the different textures, colors, and designs. Try to take in any smells and identify them. Listen for the sounds around you. Pay attention to the things you feel, such as your feet on the floor or your legs on the chair. The more engrossed in your surroundings you are, the more quickly the time will seem to pass. [10] X Research source

steps.title: Pass the time with a power nap to feel refreshed.
steps.content: Pass the time with a power nap to feel refreshed. Curl up for a quick 10-minute nap. It’s a great way to relax, feel rejuvenated, and pass some time. You’ll wake up feeling rested and energized. [11] X Research source You could set an alarm to wake yourself up or just nap until you wake up on your own.

steps.title: Turn your clocks over or hide them so you can’t see them.
steps.content: Turn your clocks over or hide them so you can’t see them. Counting the seconds can make a minute seem like an eternity. Resist the urge to check the time constantly. Put away any clocks so you aren’t tempted to look. The less you check the clock, the quicker the time will pass.
